title: 'Engravers' style (serif) and extended 'Idlewild' (sans) style
content:
Hello all, two typefaces I am hoping to identify here, 'POINT DE CROIX' and 'BUTCHER' or suggestions for suitable substitutes most welcome…

Regards

Fraher

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718im_/http:/typophile.com/files/2bd2f37262b367b3176e5334aac144cb_6163.jpg)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718im_/http:/typophile.com/files/678214285031_M9KbgTLo_l_3990.jpg)
author: Fraher

comments.content:
'POINT DE CROIX' might be [Blair ITC](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/blair) by Jim Spiece (confirmed by /G, /M and /S [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718/http:/www.behance.net/gallery/Point-de-Croix/10804917)).  
'ARROGANT' should be [Copperplate Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/copperplate-gothic) Condensed Bold.

@Don: link updated, always the same 'https' link troubleshooting...  
@Fraher: post updated for 'ARROGANT', still searching for 'BUTCHER' but I guess with a [sample from face](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718/http:/www.designworklife.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/TheArrogantButcher_01a.jpg) it could be easier.

Thought I could find a match. The closest I have for the moment is [URW Antiqua](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/antiqua) Wide/Extra Wide Bold/Extra Bold but it'd need a bit of customization.

OK, scratch URW Antiqua. Got it. That's [HI Luxury Diamond](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718/http:/www.houseind.com/fonts/luxuryfonts/viewfonts) using of the [alternate /R](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718/http:/www.houseind.com/include/getimage.php?id=6384) (new to me, hadn't noticed these aletrantes before).  
Excellent job by [TunnelBravo](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718/http:/tunnelbravo.com/?portfolio=the-arrogant-butcher) BTW.
I was thinking abut luxury but felt there was something else going on,

No need to redraw /R. Have a look to my previous post. I included a link pointing directly to the complete glyph set of Diamond and you'd see the /R they used specifically for this identity. 'Regular' /R is 2nd line 6th position (blue circle), the used one is the one after, 2nd line 7th position (red circle) and should be available as stylistic alternate through OpenType features.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718im_/http:/typophile.com/files/02_4656.png)

Last one Ryuk, what about the Fictive Script here?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718im_/http:/typophile.com/files/27ffdeb4dadb6f4332098acde189d808_4272.jpg)

Great stuff. Shows the old advertising credo "sell the sizzle not the steak!"  
Don

Sorry, Fraher, don't have the answer for 'Fictive'. It loosely reminds me of [Balmoral](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/balmoral) and [Feel Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/sudtipos/feel-script) but there might be a long way to get there starting from it. Some more I like for this job: [Yale FT](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/filmotype/yale), [Parfumerie Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/typesenses/parfumerie-script-pro), [Shelley Script/English 111](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/shelley+script) (probably my choice for customization), [Citadel Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/atcitadel-script), [Lucia](http://web.archive.org/web/20140320224718/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/lucia)
